title: I love writing and I want to start doing it every day, but I don't know what to write about. What are some suggestions? - Quora

response.answer_text: Since we don’t know one another, I’m going to have to make a number of assumptions, but I’m hoping the gist of my answer will allow you to make the necessary adjustments if my assumptions are off-base. First of all, I’m assuming you’re talking about writing fiction, since you’re looking for ideas to get you started. Second, I’m assuming that you’re an adult. If you are, your question is probably the single one most asked by people who start thinking seriously about writing as adults. Those who begin writing as kids or teenagers are usually born with the writer’s bug and seldom lack for ideas or motivation. To keep this as simple as possible let me start with the most important thing; don’t think that you have to be a “great natural writer” to start writing, or that you must produce something that will immediately become a best-selling book, or even get published. Leave all that ambitious stuff for way down the road. Your first objective is to make a start, and you’ll never do that if you’re weighing yourself down with tons of unrealistic expectations. Also, begin training yourself to avoid passing judgment on how good a writer you are until you’ve produced a lot of work. Don’t get into a competition with your favorite writers, or folks you know who are experienced writers. Leave that for way down the road, too. Your only priority is to make a start! There are countless millions of folks out there who will never write a thing because they’ve intimidated themselves into a state of permanent immobility with a lot of unrealistic expectations, one of which is that you’ve got to have a ton of natural talent to produce anything worthwhile. Forget all that. Now, as for what you should write. I don’t know you, but I absolutely know that you’ve got plenty of ammunition for a story. How do I know that? Because you’ve been alive and kicking around this planet for two or three decades at least (I’m assuming again, so adjust accordingly). You’ve been places, done things, met lots of people, gotten into weird situations, known love and loss and probably grief, and your friends and loved ones have shared a ton of their own experiences with you, so you have their lives to call on, as well. Also, if you’re thinking of becoming a writer you’re probably a pretty dedicated reader also. If you’re not a reader, you’d better start right now, because the one thing that really will prevent you from being a decent writer is not reading what other people write. And if you don’t really like to read, my suggestion is to find another avocation/activity to pursue. If you’re not a reader, writing’s not for you. Try golf instead. But I’m assuming that you are a reader, so you’ve got that experience to borrow from, as well as your own life experience. Next question is, what do you like to think about? What do you love to do? What fascinates you? Start by writing about things you know, love and know something about. If you need more information you’ve got Google, so that’s no problem. Google’s a great idea generator, by the way. Also YouTube. Start looking up details about some topic or historical event you’re really into, and use things you find to fill out your ideas for a story. Don’t worry if it’s not a long story. Length doesn’t matter - getting started does, and so does making time to write every day. It’s like taking up an exercise routine; if you don’t build writing time into your daily schedule you’ll never get into a rhythm and you’ll wind up missing more and more days until you’re right back where you started. So once you start, keep it up. And don’t worry about showing what you write to your friends and loved ones. Save the show-and-tell for awhile, until you’ve built up a little confidence and a good writing schedule. Let it be your little secret, then spring it on them when you know your stuff is going to entertain them. Finally, and most important, buy yourself a copy of Stephen King’s how-to-book, On Writing. Steve King, of course, is the world’s best-known and richest horror writer. But it doesn’t matter if you like Stephen King, or horror fiction for that matter. The book has nothing to do with writing horror specifically, or any other genre type of fiction. It’s full of sound, practical advice, and written in plain language without a hint of snobbishness or artsy-fartsy pretentiousness. King is basically a well-educated blue-collar guy, and his approach to writing is very blue-collar, with a strong emphasis on work ethic and stick-to-it mentality. Nothing I could suggest would do you more good than getting your hands on that book, and basically everything I’ve told you you’ll find repeated in King’s volume. It’s not even a long read! But most of all, just start writing, damn it! You’ve got absolutely nothing to lose, and you might be the next Pulitzer Prize winner, so get going and good luck!

Go to a cemetery and look at the broken headstone covered in weeds, with the inscription ‘Gone but not forgotten’, and wonder what that person was likeLook at the photo of dead immigrants washed up on the shores of the Mediterranean. They spent their life savings trying to get to a better lifeLook at that beautiful girl athlete, whose leg was blown off by a religious maniac when she was running a marathonRead about the heroic teacher trying to protect her young children, shot down by a depressed man who had told many that he was going to do it, and had been ignoredCheck with doctors about their cases, in particular young mothers about to give birth, and discover they have a terminal illness and will never see their child grow upOn second thoughts, don’t bother writing about such people. They have already been written about thousands of times I knowWrite about someone poor who has just won the lottery of millions of dollars, and goes on a spending spree, and is poor again in a few months Write about the father who is denied access to his children due an incompetent social worker, and he murders his children, like hundreds do every year Or how about the very rich banker who already has more money than he needs, but works out a plan to rob thousands of poor people of their retirement savings Or a good one about the person who runs a Care Home for the elderly, and treats the inhabitants very badly, and makes fun of their distress True, that these sort of stories come up every single day in the newspapers, so not very interesting Let’s consider some other ideasHow about an actress who marries a Prince. Unlikely but good for Chic LitHow about the champion athlete who is the idol of the Sports World, and is found to be a drug cheatOr the Religious leader who is found to be a pedophileOr the politician who is open to briberyOr the police chief who is friends with the mob OK, all been doneNow let me think…How can someone who loves writing, but possibly does not have something to write about? Ah! Got itWhat about the ‘All About Me’ exercises used in thousands of schools for very young children who are asked to write a storyall about me questions  Absolutely perfect for a six year old who doesn’t know what to write aboutall about me questions Yes, this is itWrite about someone who is cast away on a desert island, and finds pirates treasure worth millions of dollars, and is then rescued and brought back to civilization  And employs a top writing consultant to find a subject to write aboutThe writing consultant is absolutely brilliant, and after much research says“Sir, I have two suggestions. First you look up Writing prompts on Google, and secondly you check the 13, 774 questions that are virtually identical to your own, on Quora, and print out the answers”And the ex castaway says “Absolutely brilliant. I will call it the ‘Dummy’s guide to being a Dummy’, and it will make me rich”And the consultant says “But you are already rich”and the ex castaway says “Oh yes, so I am, that means there is nothing more left to write about”, and goes into a state of depression, and shoots himself 14 times in the head, narrowly missing his brain, and is hospitalized for the rest of his life, and the writing consultant takes all of the money, and writes a best seller called‘How to get rich quick by exploiting total idiots who asks stupid questions’ I hope that helps
